p: Selective cholesterol oxidation products, of the oxysterol family, which are ligands of Liver X Receptors (LXRs), have a well-recognized immunomodulatory role [ 3, 4]. Oxysterols such as 25-hydroxycholesterol (25OHC) have shown to markedly inhibit the replication of a large variety of both enveloped and non-enveloped human viral pathogens [ [5], [6], [7]]. However, another oxysterol of enzymatic origin, namely 27-hydroxycholesterol (27OHC), is gaining increasing consideration as a protective molecule not only against the respiratory virus Rhinovirus, but also against a wide range of other viral infections [ [8], [9], [10], [11]]. There is clear evidence that exogenously added 27OHC accumulates in plasma membrane lipid rafts, likely affecting viral entry but also modulating cell signaling stemming from such microdomains [ 12, 13].
